author: jochembrouwer
content: I have a side question for EOF regarding this. Things which we "ban" in EOF can still be reached from ETH*CALL instructions, so for instance if you want to use BLOCKHASH opcode instead of system call you can call into a legacy contract, and if you want an indication of how much GAS is left you can do the same.

author: jochembrouwer
content: Unless I've missed anything EOF can call legacy contracts - right?

author: axic3354
content: Banning blockhash is for a different reason: to simplify the semantics of eof contracts.

author: axic3354
content: Implicit observation is always a thing, but you have to also consider call targets as a black box.

author: axic3354
content: They may revert due to gas observation or any other reasons.

author: axic3354
content: What removing gas observability ensures is that eof contracts themselves cant be broken by gas alone. Third party interactions are excluded from this promise.
